moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Nf3 O-O: Most Grandmasters will play 4....c5. I prefer to castle and leave the options to my opponent as to how he will continue.
moves.5. g3 d5 6. Qb3 Nc6 7. Bg5: So White wishes to play the Leningrad Variation. But Black responds on the opposite wing, a normal practice in modern day chess.
moves.7... a5 8. a3 a4 9. Qc2 Bxc3+ 10. Qxc3 N: White should try 11. cxd. This locking of the position allows Black to build up a strong counter-attack.
moves.11... Ne4 12. Qe3: There were better ways to maintain the pressure. 12. Bxd8 seems the best way to save the position.
moves.16. Kd1 e5: A discovered attack on the g pawn which White overlooks.
moves.17. e3: White crumbles in the face of a dire situation: (17. h3...g5; 18. Bgf3...exd; 19. e3...Nxg3;  20. fxg...Nxe3+; 21. Ke2   etc.
moves.22. Bh5 dxe3 23. Rag1: White attempts a counter-attack. I had to count the moves before realizing that White will threaten mate-in-one but will be one move behind.
If now 29. Kd1...e2+; 30. Kc1...Ncd2 Mate; or 29. Kf1...e2+; 30. Kg2...Nxh4+
